title: Nanopore QC after processing
text:
Now we’ve done our preprocessing steps, we can redo the FastQC and MultiQC quality checks to see how our final read qualities are.


For FastQC, use the the result from Fastp (Read 1 Output) as input.



Input the results from FastQGroomer to FastQC


For MultiQC, select “FastQC”, and then use select the FastQC on collection: RawData as input.



Input the results from FastQC to MultiQC





You should get similar outputs that you did previously, but you should notice the reads are now only within the 1000-2000 bp range and the sequence quality remains high.



MultiQC output after processing steps showing 1500bp high quality reads


Now you can move onto Taxonomic Classification

title: Copy Datasets to your account
text:
I will have emailed you a link to the datasets from the project that you have chosen. We will have 2-4 samples from each paper.
To copy these to your own Galaxy History, click the link and then choose: “Import this History” in the top right hand corner.



Screenshot of Import this History button

text:
Now we’ve done our preprocessing steps, we can redo the FastQC and MultiQC quality checks to see how our final read qualities are.


For FastQC, use the the result from FastQGroomer as input.



Input the results from FastQGroomer to FastQC


For MultiQC, select “FastQC”, and then use select the FastQC on collection: RawData as input.



Input the results from FastQC to MultiQC





You should get similar outputs that you did previously, but you should notice the reads are longer and the sequence quality remains high.



MultiQC output after processing steps showing 400bp high quality reads

title: Illumina QC after processing
text:
You should get similar outputs that you did previously, but you should notice the reads are longer and the sequence quality remains high.



MultiQC output after processing steps showing 400bp high quality reads

title: Fastq format
text:
Fastq format
Our sequencing format has a quality score (how confident we are that each base is correct) as well as the sequence.
It can do this because all our sequences (in FastQ format) look like this:
@SRR6185165.1/1
TGGGGAATATTGCACAATGGGCGCAAGCCTGATGCAGCGACGCCGCGTGCGGGATGACGGCCTTCGGGTTGTAAACCGCTTTTGACTGGGAGCAAGCCCTTCGGGGTGAGTGTACCTTTCGAATAAGCACCGGCTAACTACGTGCCAGCAGCCGCGGTAATACGTAGGTTGCAAGCGTTATCCGGTTTTATTGGGCGTAAAGTGCTCGTAGGCGGTTCGTCGCGTCCGGTGTGTTAGTCCCTCGCTTAA
+
AAAABCCFFFFFGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGHGHH2GBGCFGE?AAAE0E0>>A0/>/E1CF1///?FGA//?F?E444B?/<CDFF2/?22//0///22/<<<FC///->-.0>1=1<0=D<D...<C0000:;--:;.0;CC9.;/9:90././9-9--9..;/999/../;..///..;A.;9/.--.;;/:9//.;9:-..////:9.;...9--;:.-99---:----;-:../9/;99/:.--;A./
Each sequence in a fastq file is 4 lines long:

Line 1: a header - a unique identifier for each read (begins with @)
Line 2: the DNA sequence
Line 3: a + to separate the sequence and quality scores
Line 4: the quality score for each base in the DNA sequence. There are more scores than there are letters, so a mix of letters numbers and symbols are used to code for the quality score.

We can use tools such as FastQC to visualise the quality scores across the whole sample - as we can’t tell just by looking at them!

title: Why preprocess
text:
The reads we have recieved from the sequencing company or downloaded from the Sequence Nucleotide Archive or European Nucleotide Database are the raw results that have come out of the sequencing machine.
We need to process these reads to do a few things. How we process the reads depends on what type of reads we have.



CutAdapt: Remove any Illumina sequencing adapters from our reads
CutAdapt: Trim low quality reads with CutAdapt, to remove possible sequencing errors.
BBMerge: Merge our forward and reverse reads, to get one longer (and higher quality) read.
FastQGroomer: Reformat the result from BBMerge to something we can use
QC after processing: Rerun FastQC and MultiQC to get our quality after these processing steps.

Go to Illumina filtering instructions




Porechop: Remove any nanopore sequencing adapters from our reads
fastp: Select only reads which are between 1000-2000 bp in length, and above a quality threshold

Go to Nanopore filtering instructions

title: Classification Overview
text:
Classification Overview
Now we have our reads, we’re going to compare them to known bacterial 16S rRNA sequences and determine the phylogenetic groups.
For some species, we will have a unique read that can give us the exact species in the sample.
However, for other species we might only be able to identify the genus as there might not be enough differences between species to uniquely identify them.
For some reads we won’t be able to classify them at all - uncategorised reads - because they isn’t enough known about these and so their sequences are not in the databases!
We’re going to use a few tools in our classification:

Kraken2 to compare our reads to a database of known sequences and output the proportions of reads belonging to each species or taxonomic group
Braken to extract some of the species level output of Kraken2
Krakentools to reformat the result from Kraken2 for Krona
Krona to generate an interactive Krona Pie Chart to visualise our data

title: CutAdapt
text:
CutAdapt
To run CutAdapt, go to Tools and Type in “CutAdapt”
Then select these options:

Single-end or Paired-end reads?: Paired collection

Choose your collection of Downloaded sequences as the input.

In “Other Read Trimming Options”

“Quality cutoff(s) (R1)”: 20

In “Read Filtering Options”

“Minimum length (R1)”: 20

In “Additional outputs to generate”: Report

After CutAdapt has run, it will generate:

CutAdapt Reads: The trimmed reads, which we will use in the next step
CutAdapt Report: A report showing you how many reads were trimmed




GIF of setting up CutAdapt


Now we’ve trimmed the reads, we can merge them…

title: Bracken
text:
Bracken will extract the species abundances from kraken2 output.
Select “Bracken” from tools:

Kraken report file: Kraken2 on collection: Report
Select a Kmer distribution: PlusPF (2021-05-17)
Level: Species
Produce Kraken-Style Bracken report: Yes




Bracken setup options




Bracken will generate a report with the abundances of some of the species in the sample:

title: The FastQC graphs
text:
FastQC creates a lot of graphs and some quality checks. The most important ones to look at are:





Quality score - what is the quality for each base in the sequence. Green region is high quality - tends to drop towards the end of the read








Sequence Length - this tells us how long out sequences are in base pairs (bp)





This one will typically fail if the reads you are looking at are a PCR product (which most metagenomics studies are!)
As we’re mostly looking for amplified 16S rRNA sequences, there will be a bias at the start of the read as they are all amplified by matching to the PCR primer.
This is also why sequence duplication and overrepresented sequences are particularly high.



Per base sequence content - not unique at the start of the read as amplified by the same PCR primers in a conserved region of the 16S rRNA gene





There shouldn’t be any adapters - bits of DNA we add to get our target DNA onto the sequencing probes - in our sequences. Let me know if there is as we might need to add an adapter removal step!



Adapter sequences detected - any detected adapters should be removed before analysis as they are added onto the sequences during sequencing, and are not from the initial samples

title: Krona pie chart: Viewing the results
text:
Krona pie chart: Viewing the results
Krona pie charts are interactive which means you can click between your different samples in the top left hand corner to compare them. You can also click onto one group to zoom into just that group.
You’ll notice the named labels start with a letter:

k_ Kingdom (Bacteria)
p_ Phylum
c_ Class
o_ Order
f_ Family
g_ Genus
s_ Species

There is also a snapshot button to download each image.
From here you can compare your samples - can you find any patterns? What could this mean, can you search for those groups and species in the literature?



Krona Pie Chart Interactive Graph
crumbs: Krona pie chart: Viewing the results

title: View FastQC results
text:
View FastQC results
Now FastQC has run, you can inspect the results.
It gives you two results - Raw Data and Website. You’ll want to look at the Website results.
You can click the results for each read pair by clicking the “eye” icon.



View FastQC GIF


However, this is a lot of graphs! We can use MultiQC to combine them.

title: Run FastQC
text:
Run FastQC
FastQC is a tool we can use to inspect the quality scores of our reads.
To do this:

Go to Tools
Type in and select FastQC
Under “Raw read data” select the folder (collection) option and then your list of sequences
Select “Run Tool”

I’ve made a GIF below to show you how to do this:



Run FastQC Tool


Whenever you run a tool it will be:

Grey when it is waiting to run
Orange while it is running
Green when it is done

title: Krona Pie Chart
text:
Krona Pie Chart
Now we’re going to visualise our results.
From Tools select “Krona pie chart”:

Type of input data: Tabular
Input file: Krakentools: Convert kraken report on collection
Provide a name for the basal rank: Bacteria

And select run.



Krona pie chart setup

title: Kraken2
text:
Kraken2
Type and select “Kraken2” from tools, and then:

Single or paired reads: Select “Single” (as they are now merged)
Input sequences: Select collection (folder) and then “FastQ Groomer on collection”
Print scientific names instead of just taxids: Yes
Confidence: 0.1
Create report:

Print a report with aggregate counts/clade to file: Yes

Select a Kraken2 database: PlusPF (2021-05-17)

Then run tool.



Kraken2 output to file

title: FastQ Groomer
text:
FastQ Groomer
Following BBMerge, we need to reformat the reads using FastQ Groomer.
From Tools, type in and select “FastQ Groomer”
Under “File to Groom”, select collection (folder) option: - Select your BBTools: BBMerge on collection (merged reads)
Make sure you’ve chosen the merged and not the unmerged reads.
Keep everything else as default, and then click Run.



FastQ Groomer

title: The MultiQC Graphs
text:
The graphs for MultiQC are similar to those for FastQC but are combined for you reads. While we have paired reads, this will combine all forward reads and all reverse reads. We’ll do this again after we’ve merged the reads, which will give us one value for every sample.


MultiQC gives you a useful overview of your samples:

A count of unique and duplicate reads. Because we’re looking at a PCR amplified genes, we expect lots of duplicates!



Sequence counts: Unique and duplicated reads. Most reads will be duplicated as we’re looking at a gene amplified by PCR





Mean quality scores for the reads.



Mean Quality Scores for the reads





You’ll also get a table of overrepresented sequences. These are all part of the conserved region of the 16S rRNA gene so are in all of our samples!

title: Metagenomics Online
text:
Welcome to the training and tutorials to guide you through your metagenomics online project!
In this book we will cover how to do bioinformatics analysis from data we have extracted from sample publications using the Galaxy project.
Click through each page on the left for a description on how to use the tools!

title: Make an account on Galaxy
text:
Galaxy Project Logo


The first thing to do is to go to the galaxy project and make an account.
Make a note of your Galaxy email address and password somewhere secure!
The Galaxy project is a free web-based tool for running bioinformatics analyses.
It runs on a remote computer which means you can run large jobs overnight and you don’t need to keep your own computer on, just check back later!

title: Porechop
text:
Porechop
During nanopore sequencing, adapters are ligated onto the DNA fragments to guide them towards the sequencing pore. This is additional DNA that wasn’t present in our samples. We need to remove these, so that they don’t interfere with our alignments - they aren’t bacterial 16S genes and hence they wouldn’t match to the 16S gene database.
To run Porechop, go to Tools and Type in “Porechop”
Then select these options:

Input FASTA/FASTQ: Paired collection

Choose your collection of sequences as the input.

In “Output format for the reads”

fastq


After Porechop has run, it will generate a collection “Porechop on collection: Trimmed”



GIF of setting up Porechop


Now we’ve trimmed the adapters, we can filter for 1000-2000 bp reads…

title: BBMerge
text:
BBMerge
BBMerge from BBTools will allow us to merge the forward and reverse reads. This will:

Give us a longer read (~400 bp instead of 2 x 250 bp reads)
Use the overlapping regions at the end of each read to select the highest quality base for each position

This is because our sequence quality drops at the end of the reads - and it is the ends of the forward and reverse reads that overlap - so effectively we’ve sequenced the lower-quality part twice and can use the two readings to increase the overall quality of the reads.
Read more here about paired-end reads here.
To run BBMerge, go to Tools and type in “BBTools: BBMerge”, then select the options:

Choose the category of the files to be analyzed:

“Paired data”

Collection of fastqsanger paired read files:

CutAdapt on Collection: Reads This is your result from CutAdapt


Leave the rest of the options as default, and click Run.
The result will give you:

BBTools: BBMerge on collection (unmerged reads) - all reads that couldn’t be merged, as they were too low quality
BBTools: BBMerge on collection (merged reads) - this is the result we want, our merged reads.
BBTools: BBMerge on collection (insert size histogram) - this is a table of values of final read length, which you could plot as a histogram in excel.




BBMerge from BBTools


The merged reads don’t come out in quite the right format, so we then need to use FastQGroomer…

title: Fastp
text:
To run Fastp, go to Tools and Type in “Fastp”
Then select these options:

Single-end or Paired-end reads?: Single end

Choose the Porechop results as your input


In “Adapter Trimming Options”

“Disable adapter trimming”: yes

In “Filter Options”

In Quality Filter options:

“Qualified quality phred”: 9

In “Length filtering options”:

“Length required”: 1000
“Maximum length”: 2000


In “Read Modification Options”:

“PolyG tail trimming”: Disable polyG tail trimming


After Fastp has run, it will generate:

fastp on collection: Read 1 output - The filtered reads, which we will use in the next step
fastp on collection: HTML Report: A report showing you how many reads were filtered
fastp on collection: JSON report: A report in a different format, showing you how many reads were filtered




GIF of setting up CutAdapt


The Fastp results will give you some tables with how many reads were filtered. These can go in the Appendix of your report.





reads passed filters:
241.989000 K (95.079603%)




reads with low quality:
74 (0.029075%)


reads with too many N:
0 (0.000000%)


reads too short:
11.955000 K (4.697224%)


reads too long:
494 (0.194097%)

text:
reads passed filters:

reads with low quality:

reads with too many N:
0 (0.000000%)


reads too short:

reads too long:

title: MultiQC
text:
MultiQC
Now we use the raw results from FastQC to put into MultiQC to generate a combined quality score.
To do this:

Go to Tools
Type in and select MultiQC
Under “Which tool was used” select FastQC
Click “Insert FastQC output”
Click “Browse or upload datasets” and select all of the “FastQC on dataset: RawData” - txt - files.
Click Run




Running MultiQC

title: Krakentools
text:
Krakentools
Select the tool: Krakentools: Convert kraken report file to krona text file
Make sure you click the “to krona text file” version as there are a few!

Kraken report file: Kraken2 on collection: Report

All other options you can leave as default.



Krakentools options

title: Inspect sequences
text:
Inspect sequences
The history you’ve been given contains a collection of paired reads.
Each sample is tagged with identifying information, for example:

#Healey2018 (the paper)
#HighFibre (the patient condition)
#Prebiotic (the experimental condition)

Some tags may have more or less information depending on how much information the paper had.
Each sample is made up of two sequencing reads: a forward and reverse sequence. This is because sequencing quality decreases along the length of the reads, so we sequence each fragment of DNA in both directions.
You can view the individual read pairs by clicking the collection, and see the sequences by clicking the “eye” icon.
You don’t need to do anything further here - we’ll use tools to tell us about what these datasets look like.



View Tags and Sequences
